doc.title: JPM | APAC Market mathematics - China: Consolidation next 3-4 months? / AXJ Strategy: Liquidity support but some crowding concerns / Thai: Top ideas / APAC Energy Transition: 10x fresh takes
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/JPM/JPM APAC Market Thematics - China Consolidation next 3-4 months AXJ Strategy Liquidity support but some crowding concern_2025-08-29

passages.text: \*\* Resending as some didn't receive the earlier version / sorry if you got it twice \*\*

First word... After MSCI China's strong rally \(+30\%\) YTD and \(+50\%\) the past 1 year, there's a case to be made for some sideways consolidation the next few months. Of note (i) Yesterday saw a record HK\$20.4bn of SB outflows - and historically, periods where we saw a big \(>HK\) 10bn outflow print have preceded sideways moves in both HSCEI and SHCOMP the next 2x and 4x weeks, (ii) Margin finance has increased by \(58\%\) y/y, and the last time this figure exceeded \(50\%\) (July- 2020), both the HSCEI and SHCOMP traded sideways the next 3- 4 months. This doesn't change our underlying constructive view on China - based on a looser policy backdrop a focus on improving the S/D balance, but it does imply a near term breather is quite likely. Elsewhere, highlighting (i) Rajiv & Mixo have published an excellent strategy note updating on positioning across the region - they remain constructive but also warn to about crowding in certain pockets of the market, (ii) Hannah & Alan publish timely note on APAC's clean energy transition, discussing the 5x key themes and 2x emerging technologies, (iii) Senior US economist Joe Lupton will host a call at 8am HK today - well worth joining.

- Tactical View: CHINA = The case for 3-4 months of consolidation (before grinding higher)- Theme in Focus: AXJ STRATEGY = Liquidity supportive, but manage risks in "crowded spaces"- US Overnight: S&P +0.3% and Nasdaq +0.5%, but Marvell -12% and Dell -5% after-hours- Thai Equities: Top ideas from our Thailand sales team (following on from the banks note yday)- Key Research: APAC Energy Transition - 10x fresh takes / India - Real & nominal convergence- Top Themes & Ideas: Market Thematics top catalyst, cyclical & value-based ideas

KEY UPCOMING JPM CALLS - APAC STRATEGY &amp; MACRO (HK time)Fri 29 Aug - 08.00amUS Macro Outlook - Views post Jackson HoleRegisterJoe LuptonFri 29 Aug - 11.45amReliance Industries - The case to say bullishRegisterSanjay Mookim, Latika Chopra, Ankur Rudra
\\* All calls for Mfid high-touch and out-of-scope clients only

TACTICAL VIEW: CHINA EQUITIES = The case for 3- 4 months of consolidation (before grinding higher) | Southbound saw record selling yesterday, net outflows of HK\$20.4bn. This surpassed the previous high of HK\$20bn on profit taking in ETFs, Semis & Robotics. Margin finance has also increased quickly, now at Rmb2.2tr (+58% y/y). Time to lock-in some gains? History suggests some sideways consolidation is likely the next 3- 4 months, before grinding higher from there. Latest views in quick Q&A format:

1. Does a big SB outflow print typically precede near-term HSCEI vs SHCOMP weakness? - Looking back over the past 5 years, the net SB daily outflow number has exceeded HK\$10bn on 12x occasions. Over the next 2x / 4x weeks, the average performance of the HSCEI was -0.1% / -1.7%. For SHCOMP, the average performance was +0.7% / -0.8%. In short, a big SB outflow print does imply a market downturn is coming - but that consolidation is likely over the next 1m.

2. Margin finance is up >50% y/y... time to worry? - Margin finance increased by Rmb815bn or +58% y/y. The y/y number is most relevant as the Govt cares more about the pace of the increase vs the size of the (now bigger) base. Looking at the last time margin finance growth exceeded 50% y/y (in mid July 2020) - what happened? The chart below shows the HSCEI and SHCOMP both went broadly sideways the next 3-4 months, before trading higher 6 months basis.

3. So multi-month consolidation? - I think so. MSCI China is +30% YTD and +50% on a 1y basis, so a period of consolidation would actually be healthy. Markets don't go up in a straight line (unless its Australia - in which case they even goes up on bad earnings!). And let's also not forget Beijing wants a "slow bull"... and >50% in 1y is not exactly slow. A period of digestion is probably what the Govt wants, to ensure speculative fever doesn't run ahead of itself.

4. What to own in China during this period? - Two sectors to say constructive into year-end (i) AI Internet - Remains well placed to adopt and monetize "AI at scale" through Cloud (supporting AI workloads), Ads (AI to drive higher click-thru rates), and by leveraging their extensive digital reach to promote new AI technologies, (ii) Large consumer leaders on 50% y/y = mid-July 2020... (i) Next 3-6m consolidation, (ii) SHCOMP > HSCEI

- US OVERNIGHT | S&P +0.3% and Nasdaq +0.5%, but Marvell -12% and Dell -5% AH. The S&P rose >6500 to record highs, buoyed by solid economic data and a weaker USD. 2Q GDP +3.3% q/q (vs 3.1% est) and initial jobless claims both beat estimates, the GDP print driven by investments and trade. Despite the stronger data, 10y yields actually fell -3bps to 4.2%, aided by a strong 7y auction. All eyes on PCE data out later today. Elsewhere in macro, the EU proposed to remove all tariffs on US industrial goods, while Germany's Merz said a Putin/Zelenskiy meeting was unlikely to materialize. In single stock, Nvidia -1% rebounded -3% intraday lows, and Broadcom +3% rose after Jensen confidently rebuffed fears of a slowdown in AI chip investment. Also saw big moves at Snowflake +20% on their stronger FY guide, which pulled up Datadog +7%, while Hormel Foods -13% fell the the most since 2008 after missing 3Q estimates and cutting guidance. Aftermarket, Marvell -12% slumped post results as 2Q data centre revenue and 3Q guidance missed, and Dell fell -5% despite their beat as the AI server backlog fell.

- THAI EQUITIES | Top ideas from our Thai sales team (Nae Thanawibulsate). Thai equities have seen renewed interest in the past 2 months, where to focus? Names we like (i) DELTA - On AI Tech upgrade and margin upside from new liquid cooling capacity as the parent-co is running out of capacity for AI product, (ii) KBANK and KTB - Offer the most upside to total payouts from 50% to 65% and eventually 80%, resulting in JPMeyield of 8-9% vs 10y Thai bond yield at 1.32%, (iii) PTTGC In chems on 70% of GDP. Where to focus from here? Alan/Hannah collaborate and discuss 5x key industry themes - submarine cables, nuclear equipment, ESS batteries, HVDC equipment and transformers, and uranium miners. They also discuss 3x geopolitical risks to watch for, 2x emerging technologies, and a refresh on our top picks in the sector (link).

- INDIA MACRO | The coming convergence between real and nominal GDP (Sajjid Chinoy). India's 2Q GDP is expected to show strong real GDP growth of near 7% y/y, driven by the services sector - which is anticipated to grow >8%. This growth is supported by a low GDP deflator due to a significant drop in WPI inflation. However, nominal GDP growth is expected to soften to 8% - the lowest in several years. This softening has implications for tax collections, debt dynamics, and expectations for credit growth and corporate earnings. Looking forward, Sajjid expects the GDP deflator to remain low, leading to a convergence in real and nominal GDP growth the next few quarters. A near 7% GDP growth rate later this week may give the impression India has been immune to the building global uncertainty in 2025 and the 10% tariffs imposed in April, however challenges such as tariffs and global uncertainty may impact future growth. Sajjid also flags the announced GST cuts could shift festival consumption to later in the year - hurting 3Q25 GDP prints but boosting 4Q25 (link).

APAC MARKET THEMATICS - KEY THEMES & IDEAS | What to own and where to focus? Our APAC Market Thematics "Top Themes & Ideas" table cuts through the noise to highlight conviction ideas across 3x distinct time horizons (i) Short-term / catalyst-based ideas, 1-3 months, (ii) Mid-term / cyclical ideas, 3-12 months, (iii) Long-term structural / value-based ideas, 12+ months.

APAC MARKET THEMATICS - TOP IDEASStrategy/ EcoHeading into a Fed "restart" rate cut cycle, the global liquidity backdrop remains supportive - with lower rates and a lower US dollar. Looking at the past 6x times the Fed re-started cuts, the USD drifted 4-5% lower the next 6m and EM equities outperformed by 5%/15% the next 6/12m. And this is not a typical Fed easing cycle... the Fed is set to ease into rising inflation, and at a time when independence concerns are growing. Lower real yields = a lower dollar, which remains 10-15% overvalued on REER. At the same time policymakers in China &amp; Korea are starting to address deep-rooted economic and policy headwinds, and Asia valuations &amp; positioning remain relatively attractive. Stay constructive.Strategy/ AnalystJAPAN BANKS - Inflation running hot, BOJ needs to hike... Japan is running a highly negative real yield policy (10Y JGB less CPI = -1.8%) policy, driving inflation. The BOJ was purposely behind the curve, but is falling too far behind, creating JGB and JPY risks. Expect +25bps hike in Oct. Topix Banks at 1x P/B are leveraged into front-end yield hikes.Strategy/ AnalystCHINA CONSUMER - Bullish into Oct Plenary... China's Oct Plenary will see Beijing discuss its upcoming Five Year Plan for the first time. This likely focuses on improving S/D including via lifting Consumption. Position ahead of the event in attractively valued consumer leaders, e.g. Anta, Yum-C, Galaxy, CR Beer all trade &lt;10x 26 EV/EBITDA.Strategy/ AnalystKOREA VALUE - Mid-cycle optimism... Post the rip, the grind higher. Valuations are now back at the LT average (KOSPI at 10.9x PE), but with 50% upside to global peer comps! Post mean-reversion, the key Q is much of the "Korea discount" will be removed. So far = are pricing zero. JPM 25-50% upside to TP in Shinhian, Samsung Life, Hynix.Strategy/ AnalystAPAC INTERNET - Adopting AI at scale... The integration of AI into digital platforms with huge distribution reach has the potential to be a game-changer for mid-term growth rates - both via Cloud growth acceleration (to support IaaS and AI workloads) and through leveraging ad-tech to boost ad effectiveness and click-through rates. Bullish BABA/Tencent.Strategy/ AnalystASEAN - Trough valuations, time to buy... Valuations are at "close eyes and buy" levels in Indonesia, and parts of Thailand &amp; Philips. Get paid to wait for the cycle to turn, with high div standout = KBANK (10%), BBRI (9%), SCB (8%) &amp; Telkom (6%) - all paying elevated dividends and at/near trough valuations. High yield plus re-rating opportunity.Strategy/ AnalystHIGH DIVIDEND - About as cheap as it gets (into a Fed cut)... High dividend as a style is undervalued, trading at near 10y wide spreads on High vs Low Div P/B across Asia. While High Div is not the style to own if cyclically bullish, it's a good hedge especially into a Fed cut cycle. Favour non-China yield plays... HK property, Indo banks, Korea banks, Korea autos.Strategy/ AnalystCHINA PIVOT - Structural policy shift... China could be on the verge of a significant pivot, with a greater focus on demand (leading to a more balanced S/D framework), while keeping policy loose (see equity vs yield disconnect). Expect ERP to compress and Growth expectations to be revised higher. Longer-term, favour ChiNext vs CSI-300.Strategy/ AnalystFINANCIAL DISRUPTION - Multi-year change... Wall Street is belatedly embracing digitalisation - via digital deposits. This is occurring alongside the proliferation of stablecoins and digital asset tokenisation. Is this as big as fiat's gold delink in terms of unleashing innovation. Key impact (i) Exchanges vs brokers - blurred lines? (ii) Payments - Rails disruption?
Source: JPM Research / Bloomberg
JPMG Page: Click here
